title: Cishan District
text:
Cishan District (also spelled Qishan; ) is a suburban <a href="district%20%28Republic%20of%20China%29">district</a> in northeastern <a href="Kaohsiung">Kaohsiung</a>, <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>.
History.
After the <a href="History%20of%20Taiwan%20since%201945">handover of Taiwan from Japan</a> to the <a href="Republic%20of%20China%20%281912%E2%80%931949%29">Republic of China</a> in 1945, Cishan was organized as an <a href="Township%20%28Taiwan%29">urban township</a> of <a href="Kaohsiung%20County">Kaohsiung County</a>. On 25 December 2010, Kaohsiung County was merged with Kaohsiung City and Cishan was upgraded to a <a href="District%20%28Taiwan%29">district</a> of the <a href="Special%20municipality%20%28Taiwan%29">city</a>.
In 2009, then Cishan Township was affected by <a href="Effects%20of%20Typhoon%20Morakot%20on%20Taiwan">Typhoon Morakot</a>.
Administrative divisions.
The district comprises 21 villages:
Transportation.
A railroad was operated by Taiwan Sugar Company for carrying sugarcanes, cargo, and passenger service from 1910 to 1978 . Trains took more than 100 minutes from Cishan to <a href="Jiuqutang%20railway%20station">Jiuqutang railway station</a>, where passengers and goods could be transferred to trains operated by <a href="Taiwan%20Railway%20Administration">Taiwan Railway Administration</a>. The track was removed in 1982 and the <a href="Qishan_railway_station_%28Taiwan%29">station building at Cishan</a> was preserved as a museum. 
Several major highways pass Cishan.
Bus transportation was provided by Kaohsiung Transportation and EDA Bus. <a href="Cishan%20Bus%20Station">Cishan Bus Station</a> is the main transportation hub of Cishan.
